plants.name: Rosa √ó centifolia
plants.description: A cultivated hybrid rose known for its large, fragrant pink flowers that bloom abundantly in early summer. Often used in perfumery and garden landscaping.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, especially Europe and North America
plants.funFact: The Cabbage Rose has hundreds of petals per flower, making it one of the most layered roses, and was historically used to produce rose oil for perfumes.

plants.name: Lilium lancifolium
plants.description: A striking wild lily with orange petals adorned with dark spots, blooming in early summer. It grows in various habitats including meadows and woodlands.
plants.location: East Asia (native), also naturalized in North America
plants.funFact: Tiger Lilies are notable for their bright orange color and lack of fragrance, which attracts specific pollinators like butterflies.

plants.name: Digitalis purpurea
plants.description: A tall biennial wildflower with tubular purple to pink flowers spotted on the inside. It blooms profusely in late spring and early summer in woodlands and disturbed areas.
plants.location: Europe, western Asia, and naturalized in North America
plants.funFact: Foxglove contains digitalis compounds used in heart medicines, but the plant itself is toxic if ingested.

plants.name: Eucalyptus globulus
plants.description: A fast-growing evergreen tree with pale blue-green leaves and globular clusters of white flowers. It blooms primarily in late spring to early summer.
plants.location: Native to southeastern Australia, widely cultivated in Mediterranean climates
plants.funFact: Its flowers have no petals; the showy white flower clusters are composed of numerous stamens, which attract pollinators such as bees and birds.
